At the height of the fire widespread flames could be seen across the site and more than 70 firefighters were in attendance. Workers, who had been processing orders and loading vans, were evacuated. There were no reports of any injuries. Crews are continuing to hose down the building. The Scottish Fire and Rescue Service (SFRS) said despite extensive damage, much of the building had been saved. sampled:
Site owner City Property has confirmed the market has been "partially re-opened". Only smaller vehicles are being allowed into the site on Thursday evening.

A City Property spokesperson said: "Our priority continues to be public safety, and we would like to thank you for your patience and support during these challenging times.

"On-the-ground teams are continuing to assess the condition of the building and work with all relevant authorities.

"As part of this process, we are currently working to reopen the adjacent car park at Redfern Crescent, with partial opening on Thursday 21st April, where smaller vehicles will be allowed in. We expect to reopen some of the lower levels over the coming days and weeks.

"We understand the inconvenience these circumstances have caused to our customers and we once again apologise for that."

Anyone who normally parks in the site on Redfern Crescent in Leigh should use the alternative Town centre car parks at Leigh Road, B2112 Chichester Road

More than 1.3m Londoners voted for him - that's almost 57% of those voting - and he quit as Mayor of London last week - now Boris Johnson is going on holiday to Greece. He posted the picture on his instagram as he waited for the plane and he said "Time to relax before the next chapter".

The former Mayor is a big fan of the Greek sunshine and we’re sure he’ll enjoy his break - with his young family. The picture shows the two little ones in a play park before the holiday. His wife, Carrie meets him out there.

Johnson is taking the kids along for the summer holiday - Lara, six, Milo, four, and baby Romy. He has posted another holiday picture from the flight out with his kids in the window. We’ve also seen pics from his holiday a couple of years ago in Mykonos - he’s a man after my own heart!

original: Three stars of BBC spy drama The Night Manager - Tom Hiddleston, Olivia Colman and Hugh Laurie - won acting prizes. Claire Foy, who plays the Queen in Netflix's royal epic The Crown, was named best TV drama actress and the show won best TV drama. In the other TV categories, The People v OJ Simpson: American Crime Story and Atlanta won two awards each. The Golden Globe Awards, which are run by the Hollywood Foreign Press Association, honour the best in TV and film from the past year. The musical La La Land swept the board in the film categories. In the TV section, The Night Manager was the biggest winner. The six-part thriller was adapted from the 1993 John Le Carre novel of the same name and made by the BBC and US network AMC. Hiddleston won best performance by an actor in a mini-series or TV movie for playing a hotel night manager

original: Spain's Christmas lottery, known as "El Gordo" or "the fat one", is a national event. It has been going since 1812 and an estimated three-quarters of Spaniards and thousands of foreigners play each year. The odds are good - around a million people walk away with cash prizes - and El Gordo is the world's biggest lottery in financial terms. It handed out 2.5bn euros last Christmas. Unlike other lotteries, players do not choose numbers. They buy a ticket with a 5-digit number on and anyone who has that ticket when the the numbers are called - or, more accurately,sung out by schoolchildrenat a televised event in Madrid - wins a share of the prize. Because of the nature of the system, tickets in a series are often sold by the same vendor, meaning the winners usually come from the same towns. The draw is always held just before Christmas to offer people some festive cheer.
sampled:
Spain's Christmas lottery, known as "El Gordo" or "the fat one", is a national event. It has been going since 1812 with the same name and is one of the world’s largest cash prize lotteries.

And it is no surprise that Spaniards take the lotto draw very seriously and believe that the 90-minute midday broadcast on television is more important than any of the three prime time football matches at the weekend - even the El Clasico, when Barcelona meets Real Madrid in the Spanish Championship.

El Gordo, which is run by Loterías y Apuestas del Estado, part of the General Directorate of Taxes and State Lotteries, and the State Lottery and National Gambling Office, has given rise to the idea that a small lottery ticket brings a windfall every day.

The prize money is spread over four draws a day but it is the national one at noon on December 22 that has the most impact on Spain

Great Western Railway warned passengers of "significant disruption". The empty train was automatically derailed after passing a red signal outside Paddington at about 18:30 on Thursday evening, leaving two of the six lines into the station out of use. Network Rail has said it will "await the conclusion of the official investigation" before commenting on the cause of the crash. As part of Wildcat Action, Rewilding Britain will help to identify potential homes for wildcats, to develop land management plans, and to gather local support for new wildcat territory. The group will also help to provide a co-ordinated approach to cat disease surveillance within these areas.

Rewilding Britain and Wildcat Action will also work directly with the small number of cat owners who still have wildcats as pets to help them identify ways to release their animals back to the wild. This will ensure that captive-bred cats are appropriately trained and supported with the correct habitat to thrive, before being released.

Rewilding Britain will also fund the Scottish Wildcat Action to continue to monitor the genetics of wildcat populations and to implement the plan to reintroduce semi-fer

original: Thanks to its location and slender shape, Panama enjoys a position as the guardian of one of the world's most important marine trade routes, which connects the Pacific and Atlantic oceans. For a hundred years the Panama Canal has provided a short cut for ships wishing to avoid the more hazardous route via Cape Horn. Panama Direct Dubbed one of the seven wonders of the modern world, the 77km (48-mile) canal is a feat of engineering that handles 14,000 ships every year along its intricate lock system. Many of these vessels fly the Panamanian flag yet the country itself has a limited history of trade. Panama only has one small shipping line as well as a number of companies providing supplementary maritime services around the ports and canal. Most merchant ships flying Panama's flag belong to foreign owners wishing to avoid the stricter marine regulations imposed by their own countries. Panama operates what is known as an open registry. Its flag offers the advantages of easier registration

Tom Pattison, from Beccles, was killed during a race at Blaxhall in Suffolk. He leaves a wife and daughter. Woodbridge & District Kart Club member Mr Pattison raced in a series of two 25 minutes races on April 23.

He suffered serious injuries during the first heat and was airlifted by the East Anglian Air Ambulance to Addenbrooke’s Hospital with serious head, chest and hip injuries.

He died the next day.

Club chairman James Williams said: “Tom was a popular member of the club. My thoughts, and those of the club, are with his family at this sad time.”

A former pupil at Bungay High School, Mr Pattison had a passion for racing.

He first started go kart racing with his mother when he was 12. He was a member of the club for more than 15 years.

He went on to race in Formula Fours on track days at his favourite circuit

Management consultant Phil Dibbs says he found it impossible to get on with one of his co-workers when they both worked for Westland Helicopters in Canada.

But he never suspected that the same employee might have been a criminal mastermind – one of Canada’s most prolific serial killers, wanted for dozens of murders.

Dibbs was told last year that the colleague he clashed with decades earlier, Robert William Pickton, is wanted by Canadian Police as the so-called “Pigman.”

After allegedly murdering young prostitutes at his farm just outside Vancouver, Pickton has been charged with 27 counts of murder.

The 57-year-old farmer and former Westland employee showed no emotion as he was led away from his farmland near Vancouver. He said he found it unfair that he was linked to such murders because the authorities didn’t have enough evidence to convict him.

Budgets for investment, known as capital, have been raided in recent years by the Department of Health to help hospitals and other trusts in England cover their running costs. The health service will save £9.2bn by the end of 2016/17.

Many wards across the NHS are in disrepair, leading to delays in operations and causing unnecessary patient suffering. Some trust boards fear going on the record for fear of being blamed and losing their job.

The latest Trust Finance Monitor report, published on Wednesday, found that only a fifth of the 210 NHS trusts with responsibility for capital investment were making enough profit to reinvest the money.

It also highlighted that trusts face an additional capital shortfall of £669m, after the government announced that it would spend less on capital than previously expected.

At the same time there is a growing backlog of maintenance work, including replacing electrical power supplies, plumbing and central heating systems.

Richard Kerr, head

original: The US boaters were part of the Port Huron Float Down, an annual event on the St. Clair River, which divides the US state of Michigan and Canada. Police in Sarnia, Ontario, said it took hours to transport the stranded revellers back to the US on Sunday. No arrests were made and no one was injured, according to police. The unsanctioned event - in which participants float down the river on rafts, inner tubes and other flotation devices - begins at Port Huron's Lighthouse Beach in Michigan and was supposed to end at Chrysler Beach in Marysville. But hundreds of people were not prepared for the strong winds and challenging weather conditions, which blew about 1,500 people out of American waters and over the border.

The statement said: “The drowning victim was with a group during the Port Huron Float Down in the Blue Water Area at approximately 2:45pm Saturday afternoon.

“The victim, a male, was taken to the hospital where he was pronounced dead.”

original: In a career spanning nearly 40 years, Frans de Waal has cemented a reputation as one of the leading authorities on the behaviour of great apes. The Dutch-born professor at Emory University in Georgia, US, has made a major contribution to our understanding of primate communities - uncovering many parallels with human societies. But he's not impressed with the way our evolutionary cousins have often been portrayed on screen. "If they were shown in a respectful way, that would be one thing. But they are usually made to be clowns, which is not helpful for the conservation case or the ethical case," he tells me. So what did this top primatologist think of the new instalment in the Planet of the Apes franchise? Dawn of the Planet of the Apes, which goes on release in the US on Friday, is a bold sequel to the 2011 re-boot. That movie - Rise of the Planet of the Apes

In a career spanning nearly 40 years, Frans de Waal has cemented a reputation as one of the leading authorities on the behaviour of great apes and the emotional lives of humans and other social primates.

De Waal, a primatologist is best known for his work with chimpanzees, exploring behaviours like tool use, altruism and empathy.

In his new book Are We Smart Enough to Know How Smart Animals Are? De Waal takes readers on a journey through the world of animal intelligence, from a chimpanzees' ability to plan for the future to an octopus' ability to escape from prison.

De Waal told Radio New Zealand's Kathryn Ryan of a recent study he was involved with that tested whether fish could recognise paintings.

"A whole lot of people in the world don't think animals, particularly fish, have a life, but we now have to see them as conscious beings and give them the respect they deserve in society."

"It is absurd that in the 21st Century we should have to live with barbaric crimes such as this." He said the authorities were working "to find those responsible" for the attack. Rio police chief Fernando Veloso told a news conference that investigators will review forensic evidence. "If these images hadn't been posted, maybe we wouldn't be here right now,'' he said, adding that many rapes go unreported.

But while all the others got their marching order, Mr Zardari was offered a more tempting deal: become president.

original: In two famous - and famously lengthy - experiments, scientists wait for pitch to drip from a funnel. It happens about once a decade, because pitch is a substance so viscous that it is, to all intents and purposes, a solid. Lives have come and gone while the drops went undripped, or fell unwitnessed. Recently, a student project in London picked up the pace, using slightly runnier pitch in a similar set-up. The invisible, inevitable progress of these inky half-fluids has captured the public's attention; the drops have acquired meaning and drama. But alongside the storytelling, Dr Kostya Trachenko is adamant there are important measurements to be made. He and his undergraduate students at Queen Mary University of London put their pitch into five different funnels, with different sized openings. sampled: In two famous - and famously lengthy - experiments, scientists wait for pitch to drip from a funnel. It happens about once a decade, because pitch is an exceptionally good insulator. * Pitch Drops - University of Queensland, Australia * Pitch Drops - Lancaster University, England The experiments Each experiment was started in 1883, nearly 130 years ago now. University of Queensland Pitch Drops The pitch (amber) drops in this photo measure about 17 mm in diameter, more than an inch. The temperature of the pitch pot today is 450 ºC. Two quartz rods about 60 cm long extend down into the pot and support the wire hook that holds the drops. The hot pitch comes to within less than 4 mm (1/8 inch) of the top of the pitch drop. The drops grow so slowly that we have over 800 of them on the apparatus.

original: Simon Berkowitz, 68, was given a six-year sentence for breaking into a retired couple's home just 16 days after being given early release. His crimes include trying to sell stolen documents in 1992 about Paddy Ashdown's affair with his secretary. Berkowitz, from Hove, denied burglary but admitted five counts of using their bank cards fraudulently. Judge Francis Gilbert QC told him: "You do not feel the least bit of sympathy for what you have done. "It is perfectly obvious you have no regrets or remorse whatsoever. Burglary is your chosen way of life. "You are a persistent burglar. You have an appalling record and it is extremely likely you will continue to offend." He broke in to the home of pensioners John and Ann Searle

The first set of burglaries were carried out while the couple, aged 74 and 72, were in hospital for their failing health.

But the elderly husband caught him red-handed in their home again as he was in the process of selling his house to an estate agent on January 1.

Mr Berkowitz, of Elm Crescent, Westcliff, was arrested and admitted five offences against the same couple at Southend Magistrates' Court.

original: Many growers blame the weak pound which has reduced their workers' earning power, as well as uncertainty over Brexit, according to a BBC survey. About 80,000 seasonal workers a year pick and process British fruit and veg. Most of them are from the European Union, mainly Romania and Bulgaria. One in five growers says they already have fewer pickers than they need. British Summer Fruits, the body which represents soft fruit growers, says labour shortages are now the worst seen since 2004. Recruitment was getting harder even before the vote to leave the EU. But the industry believes Brexit is exacerbating the problem and if access to non-UK workers dries up, it could cripple home-grown berry production. Their concern is backed up by an in-depth survey of growers by the BBC. The questionnaire was sent to members of the British Leafy Salad Association and British Summer

Many growers blame the weak pound which has reduced their workers' earning power, as well as uncertainty over Brexit, according to a BBC survey. About 85,000 workers from abroad come to Suffolk on seasonal visas to harvest fruits and vegetables, many of them from Poland.

original: For 19 years the Pococks have lived off the electricity grid, on a croft at Cougie in Glen Affric in the Highlands. They are fiercely proud of where they live and about being self sufficient. The family grows its own food - they have two dairy cows, pigs, sheep, geese, ducks and hens. Mum Sasha, 36, runs a pony trekking business while her 42-year-old husband, Iain, supplements the household income by gathering and selling scrap metal. The couple's four children - Sarah, Ryan, Ewan and Douglas - help with the running of the croft and pitch in looking after the livestock and the trekking business's 19 horses. The effort to heat and light the crofthouse, however, dominates family life. The croft is not connected to the National Grid and the family gets its electricity from a generator and a small wind turbine. But when diesel levels are low and the wind does not blow, the TV and domestic appliances are out of action

For 19 years the Pococks have lived off the electricity grid, on a croft at Cougie in Glen Affric in the Highlands – where there are just three neighbouring families. Using a wind turbine and solar panels to generate most of their electricity, they have now brought their home up to speed with modern living.

For the past few months, a generator powered by hydroelectricity from a nearby burn has provided a more reliable supply of energy.

While James works from home on his engineering business, his wife, Annabel, is more involved with their children, aged eight and three. She works one day a week at a local primary school and also undertakes charity work. They cook on a wood burning stove and heat hot water using the stove and a small wood burning boiler.

They enjoy a degree of isolation, but also access to broadband, mobile phone coverage and mains water, and have easy access to shops, the cinema and to the Highlands’ cultural offer.

Mr Graham told the committee's inquiry that Mr Cushnahan was conflicted in his Nama role because he retained shareholdings in some Graham property companies that were moved into Nama, effectively a "bad bank" responsible for recovering the value of problematic loans made by other Irish banks. original: The warning, from the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors (Rics), comes ahead of a government White Paper on housing supply, expected this month. Rics said that house hunters were returning to the market after the EU referendum in June, but there was not enough property for them to buy. It said prices were continuing to rise across most areas of the country. In October, surveyors seeing price rises outnumbered those seeing falls by a majority of 23%. That compares with 18% in September. Central London was the exception. Rics said prices there have now fallen for the eighth month in a row. "The dire shortage of available housing across the UK is continuing to push prices upwards, regardless of the uncertainty linked to the ongoing discussions surrounding Brexit," said Rics chief economist, Simon Rubinsohn. sampled:
The warning, from the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors (Rics), comes ahead of a government White Paper on housing supply, expected this month.

Despite signs of a return to stronger house price growth in April, new buyer enquiries in the UK fell to a 12-month low, according to the latest Rics Housing Market Survey.

And a shortage of sellers is set to limit the supply of homes on the market in the coming three to 12 months.

The survey shows that demand from tenants is set to increase in the near term, though long-term rental growth remains subdued.

The Rics Home Ownership Survey for April points to a marginal fall-off in interest among prospective buyers.

Potential buyers' appetite for investment properties remains lacklustre, with a near-record share of surveyors reporting lower enquiries.

Looking forward, the situation is set to worsen, as most members anticipate further decline in investment demand over the three, six and 12 month

Two people were seriously hurt and 31 others injured in the explosion on Saturday evening. The site remains a crime scene as police investigate the cause. Christine Pickup was at home with her three grandchildren at the time of the explosion. They escaped with cuts and bruises. She went to the hub earlier to find out when she can get back into her home. "I walked out in my pyjamas and a phone in my hand," she said. "Friends have put clothes on my back. Up to 100 residents and 30 business owners affected by the blast in Bebington, Wirral are being offered help from a team led by Wirral Council and the County Council.

At least 20 homes have been evacuated since the blast of Wednesday morning, with some people staying in hotels. Others are staying with family and friends. Some are temporarily being housed in a local council office.

Police have confirmed that two 999 calls were received by 999 control room from the address which was being renovated at 5.11am on Wednesday 6th July.

One caller said that there had been an explosion within the property and the caller was not at the property. Police responded to the calls and were on scene at 5.13am; they raised the alarm with the fire service as they had not found any occupants.

Firefighters attempted to put the fire out but a further two explosions followed at 5.3

Firefighters attempted to put the fire out but had no luck. A at least a third and possibly a further two explosions followed at 5.3

original: Brad Potts and Jordan Flores struck for the visitors before Jabo Ibehre pulled a goal back for Carlisle. However, Sanmi Odelusi and Nathan Delfouneso clinched victory for the Seasiders with late strikes. Potts fired his side ahead in the 33rd minute, arriving late in the box to convert Colin Daniel's cross from the left. Blackpool added a second in the 56th minute when Luke Joyce was caught in possession and Flores took advantage to unleash a fierce strike into the corner. Flores missed a chance to make it 3-0 and Carlisle hit back when substitute Ibehre headed home. But just when Carlisle were threatening to salvage something from the game, another error at the back cost them dearly as Odelusi struck for their third goal. Delfouneso closed the game out with a neat finish from 12 yards. Match report supplied by the Press Association Match ends, Carlisle United 1, Blackpool 4. Second Half ends, Carlisle United 1, Blackpool 4. Jamille Matt (Blackpool) wins

Brad Potts and Jordan Flores struck for the visitors before Jabo Ibehre pulled a goal back for Carlisle. However, Sanmi Odelusi wrapped up the points for Rochdale late on.
It was a miserable start to the match for United with defender Mark Gillespie suffering a hamstring injury in the first five minutes.
The loss of Gillespie forced manager Keith Curle to make an early substitute with Ben Barclay moving between the sticks and John Oanska coming onto the field.
It was early days yet in the game but that change unsettled Carlisle and within ten minutes Dale had taken the lead.
The opener arrived in the ninth minute. Flores played a superb cross into the box from the right flank and Potts climbed highest in a crowded penalty area to glance his header beyond O'Hanlon.
It was a deserved lead for a side pushing for a playoff spot and Carlisle did well to stem the flow of the game at this stage.
Curle's men did get themselves back into

perturbed_original: Brad Potts and Jordan Flores struck for the visitors before Jabo Ibehre pulled a goal back for Carlisle. However, Sanmi Odelusi and Nathan Delfouneso sealed victory for the Seasiders with late strikes. Potts fired Blackpool ahead in the 33rd minute, arriving from just inside the box to convert Colin Daniel's cross from the left. Blackpool added a second in the 56th minute when Luke Joyce was caught in possession and Flores took full advantage to unleash a fierce strike into the corner. Flores missed a chance to make it 3-0 and Carlisle pulled one back four minutes later when substitute Ibehre headed home. But just when Carlisle were threatening to salvage something from the game, another error at the back cost them dearly as Odelusi struck for his first Blackpool goal. Delfouneso closed the game out with a neat strike from 12 yards. Match report supplied by the Press Association Match ends, Carlisle United 1, Blackpool 4. The epic four month journey saw Anatol and Wiktor Iwanowski flee the camp in Kaluga, elude an ambush which saw two fellow escapees recaptured and Anatol shot in the hand, and survive camping in minus 20 degrees Celsius as winter tightened its icy grip. Battling fever caused by his untreated gunshot wound and without fresh water to drink, Anatol existed only on frozen berries and mushrooms, using just a makeshift compass and the stars to navigate. original: In his first interview since he fled to the UK last month, the four-star general told the BBC that Mr Museveni's plans should be opposed. Gen Sejusa fled after claiming that Mr Museveni was grooming his son Muhoozi Kainerugaba to succeed him. The government has repeatedly denied any such plan. Mr Museveni has been in power since 1986, and elections are due in 2016. The security forces last month raided the offices of two newspapers which published a confidential letter by Gen Sejusa, calling for an investigation into allegations of a plot "to assassinate people who disagree with this so-called family project of holding onto power in perpetuity". Gen Sejusa told BBC Focus on Africa that Mr Museveni was ruling over a "decadent system" and "playing God" in Uganda. "Who gave Mr Museveni the right to rule over us forever?" he asked. The claim you hear most often about the energy market is it's somehow rigged in favour of the big energy companies. There's never been a time when you need to know more about the energy market and the impact it has on the way you consume and pay. You can take back the balance by understanding the choices that other customers have successfully made. The truth is, the energy market has always gone through times when it is more expensive or cheaper to buy energy.

This is the result of a variety of different factors, none of which is as straight forward as the fact that gas and power are more expensive to buy as a result of some kind of corrupt or rigged system. Sometimes prices are higher and sometimes they are lower, it changes for all kinds of reasons and there's actually very little in the way of real power to do anything about it. Even if the market was corrupt and set up to help the big suppliers at the expense of customers, none of that would help you

sampled:
Heidi Agan, 32, now has a "bump made in various sizes", she said. The single mother-of-two from Texas is currently pregnant with her youngest child, a little girl named Emma.

She first discovered her condition, called micropsia, a year after Emma was born.

"I noticed things were getting far smaller around me," she said.

original: Duchenne muscular dystrophy affects around 120 families in Wales but the only UK centres are in England. Charity Action Duchenne said a new facility could improve the quality of life and lifespan of sufferers. The Welsh government has said it is working to improve services and support for those with muscular dystrophy. Duchenne muscular dystrophy is the most severe of the muscular dystrophies, according to the Action Duchenne charity. The charity said the disease, which affects mainly boys, was 100% fatal. Sufferers are diagnosed usually by the age of five and without good medical intervention they rarely live beyond their late teens and twenties, it said. Wales was the only country in the UK to screen newborn children for the condition, but screening was withdrawn at the end of November. The Welsh government said the test was no longer reliable. Around 100 parents and campaigners gathering at the Welsh assembly on Tuesday are also seeking matched funding to
sampled:
Duchenne muscular dystrophy affects around 120 families in Wales but the only UK centres are in England. Charity Action Duchenne is campaigning to get specialist services for Welsh families based in Wales.

One Welsh family told us: “It would be so much better to be able to attend clinics here. We travel to Wrexham hospital every single month but, because of the lack of facilities for Duchenne, we have to go to the Royal Manchester Children’s Hospital for all of the specialist clinics. It is not a sustainable situation and we have been told in the long term we will have to go up there permanently to have our son’s leg length inequality done.

“We would love to be able to stay in Wales for specialist care and the support that brings. We need a service to grow out to us, that’s all we want.”

Duchenne is a very serious condition. Every week in the UK a baby boy is diagnosed.

The government's figures are for the situation after any appeals have been completed, so they depend on how accurately it has predicted their outcome. But there is a key caveat at the bottom of the table, which is that the figures are: "Before inflation and the adjustment to the multiplier for future appeal outcomes." The inflation part is widely known. The measure of inflation used will become CPI (Consumer Price Index) instead of RPI (Retail Price Index), which will usually mean the increase is smaller, but that change will not happen until 2020. Activist Akeela Ahmed says she uses Twitter to campaign on equality issues. Her profile picture shows her in her hijab. "If I tweet something about how I feel about equality, racism or Islamophobia, people comment 'Go and read the Quran and find the right answer to that,'" she recounts. Other times, they send offensive comments about her religion – she calls them abuse.

Ahmed calls herself a Muslim feminist. She says she "feels very strongly about women's and girls' rights" and wants to see more representation in politics. But she says she is often "ignored by mainstream media".

For example, whenever she goes on TV talk shows, she says, viewers often comment on the way she wears her hijab, and why she doesn't take it off when asked. So she decided to start her own website and film interviews on issues that concern her.

"I felt like nobody hears us. I felt like we weren't heard," she explains.

original: In a speech on Sunday, following the terrorist attack in London, she said the internet provided a "safe space" for extremist ideology to breed. But technology companies and cyber-security experts have warned that tighter regulation of the internet will not solve this problem. Messages sent online can be scrambled as they leave one device and they remain scrambled until they are deciphered by the recipient's device. This is end-to-end encryption, and it stops messages being read by third parties - be it criminals or law enforcement - if they are intercepted. This adds valuable security to the messages we send online, which could contain private information, bank details and personal photographs. Some apps such as WhatsApp already add end-to-end encryption to messages automatically. However, this does mean that theoretically messages can be sent that police or other authorities cannot read if they intercept them. On Sunday, Mrs May said

original: Peter Barnes, 50, died when the helicopter he was flying clipped a crane at St George Wharf in Vauxhall, during freezing fog in January 2013. Pedestrian Matthew Wood, 39, was hit and killed by the falling helicopter. The jury found poor visibility confused the pilot and resulted in the accidental deaths of the two men. Latest updates on this case and other London stories Twelve other people on the ground were also injured in the crash. Mr Barnes, a pilot of 24 years, was under great commercial pressure to satisfy an important client that morning when he made the flawed decision to fly, which was "neither safe nor appropriate", the inquest heard. He had been flying from Redhill Aerodrome in Surrey to Elstree in Hertfordshire but was diverted to Battersea heliport. The jury accepted the Air Accident Investigation Branch's evidence that Mr Barnes experienced a "loss of situational awareness" because of poor visibility, causing the accident.
